details.title: Optimal Resource Allocation for Maximizing Performance and Reliability in Tree-Structured Grid Services
details.standardTitle: Optimal Resource Allocation for Maximizing Performance and Reliability in Tree-Structured Grid Services

p: Yuan-Shun Dai received the B.S. degree from the Automation Department at Tsinghua University, China, in 2000; and the Ph.D. degree from the Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering, National University of Singapore, Singapore, in 2004. from 2004 to 2007, he was an Assistant Professor in the Department of Computer & Information Science, Purdue University School of Science, at IUPUI, IN, USA. He is currently an Assistant Professor in the Department of Industrial & Information Engineering (IIE), and in the Department of Electrical Engineering & Computer Science (EECS), at University of Tennessee, Knoxville, USA. He has authored/edited 4 books, and published more than 70 articles. His research interests are dependability, security, grid computing, and autonomic computing. Dr. Dai is a Program Chair for the 12th IEEE Pacific Rim Symposium on Dependable Computing (PRDC2006). He is also a General Chair for the (1st, 2nd, and 3rd) IEEE Symposium on Dependable Autonomic and Secure Computing (DASC'05,'06,'07), and a Chair for the conferences of TACS'06, TAUES'05, RAMPDS'05, and ISAS'06. He serves on the Editorial Board of the International Journal of Performability Engineering, Journal of Autonomic and Trusted Computing and was a Guest Editor for the IEEE Transactions on Reliability, and Journal of Computer Science.

Gregory Levitin received the B.S. and M.S. degrees in electrical engineering from Kharkov Politechnic Institute, Ukraine, in 1982; the B.S. degree in mathematics from Kharkov State University, Ukraine, in 1986; and the Ph.D. degree in industrial automation from the Moscow Research Institute of Metalworking Machines, Russia, in 1989. from 1982 to 1990, he was a Software Engineer, and Research Associate in the field of industrial automation. from 1991 to 1993, he was with the Technion (Israel Institute of Technology) as a Postdoctoral Fellow at the faculty of the Industrial Engineering and Management. He is currently an Engineer-Expert in the Reliability Department of the Israel Electric Corporation, and an Adjunct Senior Lecturer at the Technion. He has published more than 100 papers, and two books. His current interests are operations research, and artificial intelligence applications in reliability engineering. Dr. Levitin serves on the editorial boards of IEEE Transactions on Reliability, and Reliability Engineering and System Safety.

details.abstract: The paper considers a grid computing systems in which the resource management systems (RMS) can divide service tasks into execution blocks (EB), and send these blocks to different resources. To provide a desired level of service reliability, the RMS can assign the same EB to several independent resources for parallel (redundant) execution. According to the optimal schedule for service task partition, and distribution among resources, one can achieve the greatest possible expected service performance (i.e. least execution time), or reliability. For solving this optimization problem, the paper suggests an algorithm that is based on graph theory, Bayesian approach, and the evolutionary optimization approach. A virtual tree-structure model is constructed in which failure correlation in common communication channels is taken into account. Illustrative examples are presented.

links.abstract: This paper presents a NHPP-based SRGM (software reliability growth model) for NVP (N-version programming) systems (NVP-SRGM) based on the NHPP (nonhomogeneous Poisson process). Although many papers have been devoted to modeling NVP-system reliability, most of them consider only the stable reliability, i.e., they do not consider the reliability growth in NVP systems due to continuous removal of faults from software versions. The model in this paper is the first reliability-growth model for NVP sy...

links.abstract: Grid computing is a new emerging technology aiming at large-scale resource sharing, and global-area collaboration. It is a next step in an evolution of parallel and distributed computing. Due to the large scale and complexity of the grid system, its performance and reliability are difficult to model, analyse, and evaluate. This paper presents a model that relaxes some assumptions unsuitable for grid computing systems that have been made in the existed works studying the distributed systems. The ...

context.text: However, even though failures of different resources are independent, the failure correlation of different EB exists because the resources executing the EB need to receive the data from the RMS, and send the results back [10].
The first model for analyzing the performance (service time), and reliability of a grid in the presence of the common cause failures caused by sharing the communication links was presented in [10].
This paper presents an algorithm for solving these optimization problems based on the model developed in [10].
The detailed algorithm for obtaining the probabilities \$\Pr\{\overline{E}_{1},\overline{E}_{2},\cdots\bar{E}_{i-1}\vert E_{i}\}\$ is presented in [10].

links.abstract: N-version programming has been proposed as a method of incorporating fault tolerance into software. Multiple versions of a program (i.e. `N') are prepared and executed in parallel. Their outputs are collected and examined by a voter, and, if they are not identical, it is assumed that the majority is correct. This method depends for its reliability improvement on the assumption that programs that have been developed independently will fail independently. An experiment is described i...

links.abstract: Most software reliability models assume independence of successive software runs. It is a strict assumption, and usually not valid in reality. Goseva-Popstojanova & Trivedi (2000) presented an interesting study on failure correlation among successive software runs. In this paper, by extending their results, a software reliability model is developed based on a Markov renewal process for the modeling of the dependence among successive software runs, where more than one type of failure is allowed i...

links.abstract: Model-based performability evaluation is used to assess and improve the effectiveness of fault-tolerant software. The evaluation employs a measure that combines quantifications of performance and dependability in a synergistic manner, thus capturing the interaction between these two important attributes. The specific systems evaluated are a basic realization of N-version programming (NVP) (N=3) along with variants thereof. For each system, its corresponding stochastic process model is constructe...

context.text: To estimate both the service reliability, and its performance, different measures can be used according to the specific requirements of a certain application. in applications where the execution time of each task (service time) is of critical importance, the system reliability \$R(\theta_{i})\$ is defined (according to the performability concept [23]) as the probability that the correct output is produced within a time frame less than \$\theta_{i}\$.

This allows the study of models which consider the degradation of more than one type of system component, e.g. processors, memories, buses. An efficient evaluation algorithm is provided, with an ext...

context.text: The genetic algorithm (GA) has proven to be an effective optimization tool for a large number of complicated problems in reliability engineering [26], [27].

Details on GA, and its basic operators can be found in [26], [27]. in summary, the genetic algorithm is outlined as follows:

8)
Randomly generate \$P\$ binary strings (chromosomes) for the initial population.

9)
Evaluate the fitness of each chromosome, and use a Roulette Wheel Selection strategy to select parents based on their fitness.

10)
Produce the chromosomes of the next generation by applying crossover, and mutation operators over the selected chromosomes.

11)
Form the next generation by choosing the best \$P\$ chromosomes from the pool of original chromosomes, and the new chromosomes generated in step 3.

12)
Continue step 2 until the termination criterion is satisfied.

references.title: Genetic Algorithms in Search, Optimization and Machine Learning
references.text: D. Goldberg, Genetic Algorithms in Search Optimization and Machine Learning, 1989, Addison Wesley.

context.text: The genetic algorithm (GA) has proven to be an effective optimization tool for a large number of complicated problems in reliability engineering [26], [27].

Details on GA, and its basic operators can be found in [26], [27]. in summary, the genetic algorithm is outlined as follows:

8)
Randomly generate \$P\$ binary strings (chromosomes) for the initial population.

9)
Evaluate the fitness of each chromosome, and use a Roulette Wheel Selection strategy to select parents based on their fitness.

10)
Produce the chromosomes of the next generation by applying crossover, and mutation operators over the selected chromosomes.

11)
Form the next generation by choosing the best \$P\$ chromosomes from the pool of original chromosomes, and the new chromosomes generated in step 3.

12)
Continue step 2 until the termination criterion is satisfied.

links.abstract: This paper uses an ant colony meta-heuristic optimization method to solve the redundancy allocation problem (RAP). The RAP is a well known NP-hard problem which has been the subject of much prior work, generally in a restricted form where each subsystem must consist of identical components in parallel to make computations tractable. Meta-heuristic methods overcome this limitation, and offer a practical way to solve large instances of the relaxed RAP where different components can be placed in pa...

context.text: Some other meta-heuristic algorithms besides the GA may be also applicable. for example, Ant Colony Optimization [28], Tabu Search [29], Variable Neighborhood Descent [30], Great Deluge Algorithm [31], Immune Algorithm [32], and their combinations (hybrid optimization techniques) [33] also proved to be effective in solving various reliability optimization problems.

references.title:
An ant colony optimization algorithm for
the redundancy allocation problem
references.text: Y. C. Liang, A. E. Smith, "An ant colony optimization algorithm for the redundancy allocation problem", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 53, no. 3, pp. 527-533, 2004.

context.text: Some other meta-heuristic algorithms besides the GA may be also applicable. for example, Ant Colony Optimization [28], Tabu Search [29], Variable Neighborhood Descent [30], Great Deluge Algorithm [31], Immune Algorithm [32], and their combinations (hybrid optimization techniques) [33] also proved to be effective in solving various reliability optimization problems.
